resources.string: This app needs location permissions to show its functionality.
Hosts examples to demonstrate the use of the core Navigation SDK.
Automatically download attachments for incoming emails
Only download attachments when manually requested
Hosts examples to demonstrate the use of the Navigation UI SDK.
Shows how to use the MapboxNavigation class in Kotlin code.
Shows how to use NavigationView to implement turn by turn.
Shows how to use NavigationView with a custom puck.
Shows how to use NavigationView with a custom camera tilt and zoom.
Shows how to use your own colors to style the UI SDK Components: InstructionView, SummaryBottomSheet, and so on.
Use the Navigation UI SDK\'s to show and customize a single highlighted building footprint.
Use the Navigation UI SDK\'s to show and customize a single highlighted 3D building extrusion.
Shows how to use the MapboxNavigation class with the replay engine in Kotlin code.
Shows how to use replay ride history in Kotlin code.
Shows how to use navigate to waypoints.
Shows how to observe off-route events and how to implement custom re-route logic.
Shows how to navigate from the device location to a destination using the MapboxNavigation class.
Shows how to navigate from the device location to a destination using the MapboxNavigation class from a Fragment.
Shows how to combine the Maps SDK with only the Navigation SDK and no Navigation UI SDK code of any kind.
Shows how to navigate in a free drive scenario using the MapboxNavigation class.
Demonstrates the use of a GuidanceView to show an instructional image at proper junctions.
Demonstrate how to use the MapboxNavigation class to listen for a faster route.
Shows how to integrate SummaryBottomSheet and a recenter button with the Navigation SDK.
Shows how to integrate FeedbackButton about the Feedback Flow with the Navigation SDK.
Shows how to integrate InstructionView, FeedbackButton and SoundButton with the Navigation SDK.
Shows debug points for raw(red) and enhanced(blue) location update.
Demonstrates applying a custom style for the routes.
Shows how to use NavigationView to implement turn by turn in a fragment.
Toggle the visibility of the NavigationView\'s traffic congestion layers.
An example of how to request, interpret and display route alerts
Long press on the map to place a waypoint
No available routes to that destination
There are %1$d steps in the route

This user manual has been specifically designed to guide you through the functions and features of our mobile application. 

Home = opens the home page. 

Settings = opens the settings page. 

Connect = lets the user know if the Arduino is connected to the app. 

Guide = opens the tutorial page. 

How to use the app? 
Please follow the step-by-step procedure by clicking on the tabs or by swiping to the right. 

How will I know when I have arrived at my destination? 
This app is designed to alert the user known when they are near the destination. When the user is within proximity, the app will notify the user by vibrating and beeping. 

How will I know if the Arduino is connected? 
To check if the Arduino is connected, simply go to the home page of the app and click on "Connect". A message will pop up that lets the user know if it's connected or not. 

Is the app accessible? 
Yes, this app is designed to adhere to accessibility guidelines. 

Can this app be use anytime during the day? 
Yes, this app is designed to work at any given time. At night, the Arduino will flash a light to notify anyone around of your presence.

Bluetooth must be turned on at all times in order for the app to communicate with the Arduino. 

The Arduino is designed to detect objects and will relay the proximity of the object to the app. 

The GPS tracker on the phone must also be on at all times in order for the app to accurately determine your distance from the destination. 
Furthermore, the app will require the user to turn on their GPS tracker in order to see the listed the available locations provided by the app. 

What happens if my GPS gets disconnected mid-way through the route? 
Once the GPS tracker is re-connected, the app will re-calibrate your location and route.

Choose one of the following categories listed in the screen. 

The available categories are: 

Classrooms: this category will list the buildings were lectures are conducted. 

Study: this category will list the buildings and places for you to study and do homework. 

Restaurants: this category will list all available areas were you can eat or buy food. 

Services:this category will list the buildings with special services such as security or disability services. 

Student Stores: this category will list the buildings where students can buy school supplies or university merchandise. 

Fitness: this category will will list the buildings and areas were students can exercise. 

All Locations: this category will list all of available buildings and destinations listed.

Choose one of the available locations listed by simpling tapping on the tiles. 
You can scroll-down or type the name of the building in the search bar. 

The distance between you and the building is also provided in feet. 

If you would like to call the buildings main phone number, simply tap the phone icon. 

If you would like to know more information about the building, turn on your volume and click on the information icon. An audio will be played.

Follow the directions provided or simply listen to the audio guide. 

The app will starting making a beaping sound once you are within a close proximity of the door. 
Furthermore, the app will also relay back the distance between the user and the door.
You have arrived at your destination. \n\nOnce you are within a close proximity of the door, the beacon will be turned off and the navigation will terminate.
